description: {"blocks":[{"key":"olpo","text":"Fluorometric assay for precise measurements of ammonium from 0.3 to 50 µmol•L-1 concentrations. Reaction reaches maximum fluorescence after ~2 hours and remains stable for several more hours. Single, non-hazardous working reagent is stable for months. NOTE: This protocol is written for measurement in 96-well plates—adjust reaction volumes if using fluorometer for measurements.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bbmmo","text":"Reference: Holmes, R.M., A. Aminot, R. Ke?rouel, B.A. Hooker, B.J. Peterson. (1999) A simple and precise method for measuring ammonium in marine and freshwater ecosystems. Can. J. Fish. Aquat. Sci. 56: 1801–1808.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
materials_text: {"blocks":[{"key":"6dp15","text":"Fluorometer (or plate reader)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"l7vt","text":"200 and 1000 µL filter tips","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5uj6r","text":"200 and 1000 µL pipettes","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a4n3v","text":"microcentrifuge tubes","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3g99t","text":"Tube racks","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"jm99","text":"15 mL conical tubes (for standards)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1bdls","text":"Vortexer","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eogqd","text":"96-well microplate with lid, black (preferable)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"diqfb","text":"Working reagent ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1vfbb","text":"Ammonium standards ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fagf0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"816d2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

status.info: We use this protocol and it’s working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3vvha","text":"1. Prepare 200 µM stock solution: Dilute 1:500 from 0.1 M solution =\u003e 20 µL + 9.980 mL nanopure water.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"83aej","text":" Dilute the stock solution to the following concentrations ( µM) in nanopure water: 0, 0.5, 1.25, 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10. NOTE: 1 mL of each standard is necessary for triplicate reactions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bhdvg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"1u6q1","text":"Prepare Reagents and Solutions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bgf1t","text":"1. Sodium sulfite solution: Add 1 g of sodium sulfite (Sigma S-4672) to 125 mL of nanopure water. The resulting solution is stable for ~1 month when stored at room temperature in a glass bottle.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c95dv","text":"2. Borate buffer solution: Add 80 g of sodium tetraborate (Sigma S-9640) to 2 L of nanopure water. Stir or shake thoroughly to dissolve.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2orvj","text":"3. OPA solution: Add 4 g of OPA (Sigma P-1378) to 100 mL of ethanol (use a high-grade ethanol because impurities in ethanol can autofluoresce). OPA is light sensitive, so it should be protected from light while dissolving in ethanol and stored in the dark.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8s3ta","text":"4. Working Reagent: In a large (\u003e2 L) brown polyethylene bottle, mix 2 L of borate buffer solution, 10 mL of sodium sulfite solution, and 100 mL of OPA solution. Ideally, allow the WR to “age” for 1 day or more prior to use because its blank will decrease over time. The resulting WR is stable for at least 3 months when stored in the dark at room temperature, or longer when stored at 4ºC. The final WR should contain the chemicals at the following final concentrations: borate buffer (40 g·L–1, 21 mM), sodium sulfite (40 mg·L–1, 0.063 mM), and OPA in ethanol (50 mL·L–1).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"reuu","text":"A. Assay set-up.NOTE: This procedure can be modified for 24-well plates by increasing reaction volumes 4X and preparing reactions in 15 mL conical tubes. 24-well plates hold up to 2.5 mL per well.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"u13","text":"1. Label one microcentrifuge tube for each sample, blank, and all standards (7). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"18bjn","text":"2. Working under dimmed light, aliquot 1 mL of Working Reagent (or nanopure water, as appropriate) to each reaction (or blank) tube.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"asm0a","text":"3. Add 250 µL of sample, standard, or nanopure water to each corresponding tube.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f259u","text":"4. Mix (invert or vortex) and incubate in the dark at room temperature for 2-3 hours.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"81h9j","text":"5. Transfer 250 µL of each reaction to triplicate wells of a 96-well microplate and measure fluorescence on plate reader.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"87edq","text":"B. Reading plates.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ene1e","text":"1. Turn on Tecan Infinite 200 PRO plate reader 20-30 minutes prior to use.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"87j9h","text":"2. Once warmed up, open the iControl software on MLCLab-PC.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fm3dh","text":"3. Open file “OPAammonia_96well” (or “OPAammonia_24well” if appropriate).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8fmcf","text":"4. Load the plate—check whether the “plate with cover” box is checked (can read with lid if using clear plates but make sure to remove lid if using black plates).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3iftv","text":"5. Read plate at 350±9 nm excitation and 422±20 nm emission (fluorescence top mode, manual Z-position set to 24995 µm, 25 flashes, manual gain of 100, 20 µs integration time). Program automatically opens an Excel file that documents parameters and data.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"16mfn","text":"C. Analyzing data.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d7pgo","text":"1. Subtract the fluorescence values of the samples mixed with nanopure water (or borate buffer, preferably) instead of the Working Reagent (sample blanks) from the corresponding reacted sample fluorescence’s (= corrected sample fluorescence).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"aeja0","text":"2. Subtract the average fluorescence of the nanopure water tubes (i.e., 0 µM ammonium) mixed with borate buffer instead of Working Reagent (standard blanks) from the fluorescence values of all the standards.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d1sn","text":"3. Plot corrected fluorescence (y) vs. concentration (x) for all standards to establish a standard curve with linear regression.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bhcuj","text":"4. Use the equation of the standard curve to calculate sample concentration from fluorescence.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

title: Measuring ammonium (NH4+) concentrations in water samples

versions.title: Measuring ammonium (NH4+) concentrations in water samples
